and um the other big difference is that there's extreme platform heterogeneity
in Android and what what I mean by that is fragmentation basically so there's lots of different types of devices big
ones small ones keyboards cameras dual cameras um some have the new NFC readers
so when you're developing an application if you want to develop a good application you either need to make
limitations on what your app can do and what Hardware needs to support it or you need to keep in mind all the different
variations that are available so for example a good application like say a Twitter for example should be able to
run reasonably well on a very small cheap phone that's being sold in the Third World um or on you know the latest
and greatest dual core processor that's coming out from Motorola for example so there's quite a diversity in
terms of what uh what different Hardware is available so now I just wanted to talk
briefly about the and stack and give you an idea of how the platform is built up just so you can get an idea of what
you're interacting with so my favorite part personally is the bottom the Linux kernel but I won't bore

bunch of libraries most of them are open source C C++ libraries those are the ones in green and um you can actually go
and get the source for those if you want another big component is Android
Ro's virtu Java virtual machine it's not a true Java virtual machine because it
doesn't actually run Java B code it actually runs something called dvic bite code but the way that Android set up the
tool chain you develop your app in Java it's compiled to Java B code and then it
gets sent to the dvic um virtual machine and actually run so from your perspective it really doesn't matter but
what that means is not every single Java Library out there is going to be able to work correctly on this virtual machine
but I'm not I'm not aware of any big ones that aren't supported and then the blue section
second to the top is the application framework as an application developer this is where you're going to spend most
of your time Android has um one pattern that I think is most pervasive which is
the manager pattern and what happens is if you want to talk to any sort of shared resource
you usually end up talking through a something manager so for example if you want the location of the device you go
to location manager if you want to send a notification to the user you go to the notification manager if you want to uh
bring up the phone the phone dialogue you go to the telephone manager and so on and so forth so if you're trying to
figure out how to do something on the platform a lot of times you'll be asking yourself which manager do I need to talk
to and depending on the service you might have to get permissions as
well the the security model for Android on on app layer is basically uh they
give you I I personally think they could do a better job on this but that's the way it is is when you install the app it gives you a big list of what permissions
the application is asking for and then you agree to all of them and the application can do it all the time which
is a little different than the other platforms which might ask you more than once okay another uh big difference with
Android is What's called the activity life cycle so for those of you coming from desktop platforms or maybe from the
web this is quite different and the reason that there's an activity life cycle is
because power and uh network connectivity that sort of thing is is
very scarce on a mobile platform so an Android application has a few different
states that it can be in so the I I like to pair them into threes because I think they make sense uh because all three
pairs are coming in and out of a certain state so the the first to oncreate and
UND destroy that is basically when you create the application at the very beginning and when you destroy it and
remove it from memory so you see how those two kind of go together then there's on stop and on start that is
when the application is actually uh shown and then not shown to the user and then there's on resume and on
pause which toggle based on whether the app the activity is hidden meaning it's
behind a another activity or if it's fully visible so the activity life cycle
I think is really confusing for new developers but if you think about it in in those three pair of two methods I I
personally think that's the easiest way to to deal with it okay um so for those
of you that are uh just getting into this game I and you want to get some Hardware I highly recommend that you get
